 I guess this can reduce to the question of whether there is such thing as free will, in whatever sense of the term.

 Hume didn't say that 'nothing can be real if it cannot be directly observed by the human eye'. In fact he believed in cause and effect. However, he pointed out that causation remains unproven. This, combined with causation's inadaquecy with First Causes led to Kant's placing of cause and effect in the 'phenomenal' world of how we see things, not the 'noumenal' world of things in themselves. This does not mean that some form of causation does not exist in the noumenal world, just that we don't know it does.
 
 The interesting implication is that free will is just the way we organise our thoughts, but then so is causation. Neither has more validity than the other. And 'proofs' of causation assume causation, just as 'proofs' of free will assume free will.
